Source: example adopted from Kahn & Valijärvi (2022, p.180)

Translation: fast compared to the other competitors
Comment: The case and number of the modifier matches that of the associated noun (Kahn & Valijärvi_2022, p.123).

Translation: My sibling has a big house.
Comment: There are also suffixes with a specific adjectival meaning which can be added to nominal stems, forming a new noun with a meaning equivalent to an English adjective-noun phrase (Kahn & Valijärvi_2022, p.127). Suffix -(r)suaq: big.
The modifying intransitive participle is formed by adding the suffix +toq or +soq to a verbal stem (Kahn & Valijärvi_2022, p.119).

If an incorporated predicative is accompanied by a modifier, the modifier follows the incorporated predicative and appears in the absolutive case. See section 14.2.1 in Kahn & Valijärvi (2022) for more discussion.

If an incorporated direct object is accompanied by a modifier,the modifier appears in the instrumental case. The modifier can precede or (optionally) follow the noun. See section 14.2.1 in Kahn & Valijärvi (2022) for more discussion.

If an incorporated direct object is accompanied by a modifier,the modifier appears in the instrumental case. The modifier can precede or (optionally) follow the noun. See section 14.2.1 in Kahn & Valijärvi (2022) for more discussion.

Translation: I’m just going to help my mother, who is washing up in the kitchen.
meat that is fried/ fried meat
Comment: If the relative element is the object of the relative clause, +toq/+soq is not used. Instead, the verb takes a passive participle suffix (Kahn & Valijärvi_2022, p.331).

Translation: the hunter who killed a/the bear
Comment: Relativization of the subject of transitive participial inflected forms requires to subsititute the transitive verb to a ‘half-transitive (HALFTR)’ form with instrumental case object (Fortescue_1984, p.54).

Translation: 14-year-old children from various settlements (i.e. 'those from various settlements (who are) 14-yearold children')
Comment: If the relative clause precedes the nominal it appears to modify,it is emphasized in relation to the latter: one may then say that the relative clause itself is the head of the NP (Fortescue_1984, p.109).
These forms take standard intransitive verbal endings (Kahn & Valijärvi_129).
suffix -llarippoq/-llaqqippoq has the meaning of ‘to be good at’ and it is attached to the verbs (Kahn & Valijärvi_2022, p.131)

Translation: a previous supply ship to Nuuk
Aningaaq is a soldier in the Danish army.
a well-spoken old Greenlandic female servant
